meta.title: ePBS vs 6-Second Slots: Glamsterdam's Consensus Layer Fork Choice
meta.author: Jason J McPheron (jmcpheron.eth @jmcpheron)
meta.description: Comparing EIP-7732 (Enshrined PBS) and EIP-7782 (6-Second Slots) for the single consensus-layer headline slot in Glamsterdam

sections.constraint: Only one consensus-layer headliner will be included in Glamsterdam. Final decision scheduled for ACDC #162 on August 7, 2025.

sections.reasoning: Speaking as a long-time Ethereum enthusiast, community member, and solo staker supporter, I strongly prefer ePBS. While I appreciate the merits of both proposals, the urgency and benefits of enshrining Proposer-Builder Separation sooner rather than later drive my preference. Current data shows just two builders (Titan and beaverbuild) control >84% of blocks, and this concentration continues to grow. Although the free-option problem is real, it is overstatedâ€”practical limits such as builderâ€“searcher relationships, reputation systems, and the current ~8 s reveal window make systematic exploitation difficult. Mitigations like asymmetric payments, penalties, and shorter reveal windows can further reduce risk. 6-second slots would deliver a nice UX improvement, but this can be safely implemented in a later fork. The benefits of addressing relay dependence and enshrining PBS at the protocol level merit prioritization in Glamsterdam.

data.laymanDescription: Proposes the decoupling of the consensus block from the execution payload, both in broadcast and validation. This feature enables L1 scaling by significantly changing the time required to both broadcast and executing the payload together with all the blob data, from the current ~2 seconds to aproximately ~9 seconds. It allows for a maximum portion of the slot to be spent in propagation large data.
benefits: Better slot utilization getting close to 100% utilization for broadcasting + execution
Removal of most of the heavy work from the hot path of block validation.
Removal of trust assumptions for proposers and builders.
Removal of trust assumptions on off-protocol closed source software.

data.laymanDescription: This reduces Ethereum's slot time from 12 seconds to 6 seconds, making Ethereum a better confirmation engine for apps and rollups. Everyone benefits: users get faster confirmations with better censorship resistance, DeFi gets more efficient trading with lower fees, stakers get lower reward variability, and nodes get better resource utilization with smoother bandwidth usage.

Makes DeFi exchanges more efficient with frequent price updates and reduced arbitrage losses
Creates healthier block construction markets with more frequent, smaller auction opportunities
Improves interoperability with faster L1 finality for rollups and bridges
Reduces staking reward variability, benefiting solo stakers and home operators

Enables flywheel effects attracting more liquidity and traders to Ethereum
Maintains current throughput while doubling proposer frequency per unit time

sections.title: Relay Concentration Crisis
sections.content: As of July 2025, just two builders control >84% of Ethereum blocks: Titan (titanbuilder.xyz) at 47.45% and beaverbuild.org at 36.97%. This concentration has grown since early 2025 and represents an existential threat to Ethereum's credible neutrality. Every month we delay ePBS, this oligopoly strengthens.
The Free Option Debate (Updated from ACDC #161)

sections.topic: Is the free option problem a dealbreaker for ePBS?

perspectives.label: The free option is a serious risk
perspectives.author: Flashbots Research (presented at ACDC #161)
perspectives.argument: Builders get an 8-second window to observe market volatility after committing. During extreme events, they can abandon blocks worth $100-300 in expected value. This could lead to cascading empty slots during the exact moments when users need reliable block production most. The game theory is clear: rational builders will exploit this option. At ACDC #161, we demonstrated how builders can exploit the 10-second blob submission window to strategically invalidate blocks after market conditions change.

perspectives.label: The free option is manageable
perspectives.author: Terence (EIP-7732 co-author)
perspectives.argument: The free option exists because we're maximizing slot utilization - extending blob broadcast from 2s to 10s. It's hard to exploit in practice: builders must maintain relationships with searchers and proposers, everyone sees the revealed payload context, and refunding searchers erodes profits. Plus, we can implement asymmetric payments as additional deterrent. Multiple mitigations exist: shortening the window to 3-6 seconds, introducing penalties for non-release, or dynamic penalties similar to EIP-1559.

sections.position: The free option problem shouldn't derail ePBS
points: The tradeoff exists because we're scaling - without extending blob time to 10s, there's minimal free option
Builders have two-sided relationships (searchers and proposers) that constrain bad behavior
After payload reveal at 9s, everyone sees transaction context and versioned hashes
Breaking searcher agreements requires refunds that reduce free option profits
Proposers won't add random builder endpoints - reputation matters even with p2p bids
Stress tests show ePBS handles high load better: 0 orphaned blocks vs 28 with current Electra
Validators can't easily disable blocklisting without reputational consequences
counterpoints: During extreme volatility like liquidation cascades, even reputable builders might rationally abandon blocks
The cumulative effect could still harm user experience during critical moments
Social slashing is fragile - validators may disable blocklisting for higher revenue

sections.title: EIP-7886: Delayed Execution Alternative
sections.content: Some developers propose EIP-7886 (Delayed Execution) as an alternative slot restructuring approach that avoids the free option problem. However, this approach has less client support and doesn't achieve the same trust minimization benefits as ePBS.

sections.topic: Which proposal should take Glamsterdam's single CL slot?

perspectives.label: Prioritize ePBS - Fix MEV Now
perspectives.author: Protocol Researchers & Client Teams
perspectives.argument: The relay oligopoly is an existential threat to Ethereum's credible neutrality. Every month we delay ePBS, relay dominance grows stronger. The free option concerns are overblown - practical constraints and mitigations make it manageable. If we don't enshrine PBS now, we may never get another chance as vested interests solidify. Real-time proving is approaching 12 seconds, making slot restructuring urgent for ZK integration.

perspectives.label: Prioritize 6s Slots - Users First
perspectives.author: App Developers & L2 Teams
perspectives.argument: Users don't care about relay architecture - they care about responsive apps. Halving confirmation times would be immediately felt by millions. ePBS is important but can wait for the next fork when we've had more time to fully address all concerns. Let's ship the obvious UX win now and tackle the complex MEV restructuring when it's fully baked.

sections.title: The Clock is Ticking
sections.content: The August 7, 2025 ACDC #162 call will make the final decision. Client teams need clarity by then to begin implementation for the 2026 Glamsterdam upgrade. Both proposals have merit, but only one can claim the consensus layer slot. Current client support leans toward ePBS, with Lighthouse, Prysm, Grandine, and Lodestar all selecting it as their preferred headliner.

The choice between ePBS and 6-second slots represents a fundamental tension in Ethereum's evolution: protocol health versus user experience. ePBS addresses an existential threat to decentralization with manageable risks - the free option problem, while real, is constrained by practical market dynamics and can be further mitigated through penalties, shorter windows, and reputation systems. The relay oligopoly has reached crisis levels with just two builders controlling >84% of blocks. 6-second slots deliver immediate, tangible benefits to users and L2s but do nothing for MEV or scaling. The community must weigh immediate gratification against long-term protocol sustainability, knowing that this decision shapes Ethereum's trajectory for years to come. Given the growing relay concentration and strong client support, ePBS deserves priority in Glamsterdam, with 6-second slots following in the next fork.
